habitat_description:
The description of this species’ range by Stebbins (2003) requires confirmation, as studies performed by Leavitt et al. (2007) confine Xantusia arizonae to a smaller area of Arizona in comparison to previous findings. Papenfuss et al. (2001) determined this species to be endemic to a relatively small area of Arizona mainly characterized by granite outcrops. The Arizona night lizard can be found under exfoliating rock, but also nearby bare rock, talus, and scree. 

This area in Arizona, is located west of the Verde River in the Weaver, Date Creek, and McCloud Mountains where the habitat is characterized by Manzanita, shrub oak, mountain mahogany, silk tassel, one-seed junipers, and Emory oaks (Jones and Lovich 2009). More specifically, this night lizard occupies crevices of granite boulders, packrat nests, banana yuccas of the upper edge of the Arizona Upland Sonoran Desert.

Bare rock, talus, and scree. Manzanita, one-seed juniper, banana yuccas, shrub oak, silk tassel, and mountain mahogany.
